I do.

We follow both Mahavir ji & worship almost all Hindu Gods too.

I understand that just like Sikhism, Buddhism, Hinduism & Jainism are all Indian/Dharmic religions. We have more similarities & minute differences. All the Dharmic/Indic faiths preach only peace & non violence against others. All the Dharmic religions believe in equality, universal brotherhood and none of Indian religions are against atheists.

We believe in living a peaceful & carefree life. It doesn't bother us if you worship this God or that God, if you are from India or somewhere else. We don't mind people of other religion or even atheists. Our religions have co existed for many centuries. We don't believe in converting non Dharmic people or in killing someone because they are from different faith. Atheists are welcome. (Not anti theists, sorry.)

We are not like political religions of middle East namely, joos, Isais or mullas. We have been here since the beginning & will always be here. We welcome refugees who are persecuted and also stand firm against outsiders who intend to conquer our people or our land.

Peace, motherland, mother tongue & our own people are the things without which we cannot live. Must have at least two. We welcome foreigners with folded hands & greet foreign enemies with weapons.

Thanks

Jay Hind

Jains, the believers of Jainism are known fOr magnificent temples. The question is why Jains prefer having or constructing temples instead of praying at home.

Three reasons I see.

  1. Jains believe in teachings of 24 divine Tirthankaras, last being Mahavir for the current era is believed to have lived 2600 years ago, since there is no Tirthankara at present, there's no pious assembly i.e Shamavsharan where Tirthankaras give sermons, temples in Jainism is mere representation of that preaching hall, a replica of Tirthankaras sabha, Jain's believe that In temple they can feel the auspiciousness and peace similar to which was present when Tirthankaras were dwelling this very earth.
  2. Jains also believe that no matter how much we try at home, it's near to impossible to create that sacred environment at home like we get in temple. At home we do many works which aren't appropriate like we gossip, people bitch, eat, fight, make love, poop and what not. The energy levels and environment at home is quite not suitable. This simply doesn't make home a good place for meditation and aren't sanct enough to keep idols.
  3. Walking to a temple is putting an effort, reaching a temple is significant dedication and performing pooja bhakti meditation or reading scriptures is determination. With the beginning of thought 'lets go to temple’ one gets an directed orientation, an aim is generated and efforts followed. Once the task is performed the peace and satisfaction is one that's acheived.

These are some of the many reasons why Jains have temples, why they prefer worship away from their homes in beautifully constructed temples. And I find these reasons quite amazing.

Jain temple, New Delhi, India.

Peace~

Do Jains worship Hindu Gods?

Yes! Being a Jain, I have always considered myself as Hindu, If someone asks me only identify between being Hindu or being Jain, I will choose being Hindu hands down! It is common for us to keep fast on Mondays (Lord shiva), my family members keep them. Especially in shravan

My family, forefathers and almost all my relatives pray to Lord Shiva, shiv temple is a place where I find solace and that sense of oneness. I can't resist the temptation of bowing to a him, I don't ask him anything, I just go there to say him thanks.
I pray to ma saraswati, Lakshmi, in fact Maa Amba is our kuldevi, and we go to their shrine in Mount Abu once in a while.
I never read Agams but have explored bhagvadgita because it inspires me. Jainism teaches me non violence but Hinduism is core to my life. My father always encouraged me to emulate virtues of Rama. And lessons of Lord Mahavira came much later in my life. I write OM the Hindu way in sanskrit and not in Prakrit.
I have never felt that I was not a Hindu, I was never discriminated.

Why have Hindus stopped the practise of converting the oldest son to Sikhism?

Guru Nanak's Sikhs never sought an active conversion to their faith, By faith, I would mean their way of prayer and living, The way of a Sikh was service to humanity, like making Dharamsala (free place to stay and eat for travelers), Dig Sarovars so that water scarcity of village both for humans and animals is solved. Guru Har Rai Sahib had an Ayurvedic dispensary which was the worlds best at the time where the Son of Jahangir came for treatment. Taking care of flora and fauna was an important part of Sikh life.

Polygamy, Sati Pratha(widow-burning) and Pardah(covering of Face by women) were pro

Guru Nanak's Sikhs never sought an active conversion to their faith, By faith, I would mean their way of prayer and living, The way of a Sikh was service to humanity, like making Dharamsala (free place to stay and eat for travelers), Dig Sarovars so that water scarcity of village both for humans and animals is solved. Guru Har Rai Sahib had an Ayurvedic dispensary which was the worlds best at the time where the Son of Jahangir came for treatment. Taking care of flora and fauna was an important part of Sikh life.

Polygamy, Sati Pratha(widow-burning) and Pardah(covering of Face by women) were prohibited among the followers of the guru. Gurus encouraged widow remarriage and gave an equal position to women in society. Those Hindus who were spiritual seekers liked these concepts and got attracted.

All religious places when become big attract men whose aim is corruption and exploitation. When we read the writings of Kabir and Nanak we find there is a lot of criticism of the practices of the temples of those times. Priests used to extract money and belongings from innocent people using their corrupt tactics.

Now coming to Hindus making their first son Sikh, Let us understand what kind of Hindus were these? The first son is always the most loved member of the family, would you make him follow a religion or practice in which you do not have any faith in? Will a Hindu ever make his son a Muslim? Even if a parent decides to make his son follow some other religion from his own, how will you teach him to pray in some other way than your own? Something which you do not know. Practically not possible.

So my understanding is that these were people who adored the idea of service in the teachings of the gurus. And they revered these teachings and made those teachings the core principle of their life. And these people used to read Gurbani and do Gurbani Paath, Many had Guru Granth Sahib Prakash in their houses.

(Every Hindu home in Punjab had small Gurbani books ‘Gutka Sahib’ till around Swami Dayanand Started his Hindu reform movement there, he disliked the idea of Hindus doing Japji Sahib or Sukhmani Sahib Paath and visiting gurudwaras for prayer. He criticized the Bani of Guru Nanak. Arya Samaj )

Coming Back to the original topic, The transition to Sikhism was a very very slow process. Like I have my friends who are Vaishnavas or yogis/Buddhists but slowly they start appreciating the ideals of Guru’s teachings more and more. And start serving in the langar, and various other community service programs. There are some people who like the Sikh ways, But since they were not themselves used to keeping long hairs, they would resolve that at least they would make their son or Grand Son as Gurus Sikh. They themselves remainder as Sahajdhari Sikhs (Clean Shaven people who would resolve to slowly and steadily start living by the teachings of the Gurus).

They only made the first son as Khalsa Sikh or GurSikh or KeshDhari Sikh, because there was a price on the head of a GurSikh whether dead or alive. So they gave the most lovable thing of their life to the Guru, their firstborn son.

Ask any parent how much they love their son, to give them for dying on the battlefield was not an easy thing. This is not possible unless their ultimate faith was in Guru.

In the Guru Granth Sahib, you would find there is a criticism of Idol worship, But at the same time, Sikhs are taught to respect others faith, and be very tolerant and loving towards people following other traditions.

Although there is a criticism of both the Idol worship of Brahmanas as well as the Muslims way of Namaj Kabba, Hajj in the Guru Granth Sahib, At the same time a Sikh has to understand that within the Idol, and within the Namaj or Kabba of the Muslim the same Waheguru Resides.

It was this tolerant loving nature of Sikhs and attitude of Service that spread Sikhism and both Hindus and Sufi Muslims came closer to Sikhs, It is to be noted that not all orders of Sufism were proselytizing or violent, There were many Muslim followers of Guru, who Lived and died as officially Muslims because leaving Islam was punishable by death.

Although the Sikh Scriptures were critical of Idol worship, Sikhs did not oppose Idol worship in any way. The Sikh way was that of Shabad and Seva, and it did not pose any problem if someone else was doing worship in his own traditional way. This acceptance of the way of the other person brought the followers of Gurus not to enter into any kind of religious conflict with the followers of Sanatana Dharma or with followers of the Sufi Orders.

Not everyone aims to live in Samadhi as Jeevan-Mukta, The purpose of Guru Granth Sahib is Spiritual emancipation, Many people would be surprised to know that there is no mention of any rituals practices of Sikhs in Sri Guru Granth Sahib. There is no mention of 5 Ks too.

So when Guru Granth Sahib contains criticism of Idol worship, these teachings are for those who are looking for the Highest realizations while working as a karma-yogi and doing works of daily life as a householder. The criticism of Idol worship is not there for you to empower you to criticize your Hindu friend who is visiting a temple to pass in his examination or get promotion in his job, It was for your own introspection of what you have to do and not do. This deeper Spiritual understanding united both Hindus and Sikhs together.

So coming back to the original question Why have Hindus stopped the practice of converting the oldest son to Sikhism?

Hindus have stopped doing so because Sikhs stopped understanding the deeper meanings in Guru Granth Sahib and started criticizing Hindus and their practices which made them stay away from the Sikhs.

Surprisingly very few Sikhs now try to study and understand Guru Granth Sahib themselves, and you need to ponder deeply to understand the deeper meaning and intent, What they do is just hear some college professor or preacher who is more interested in getting a Ph.D. for his thesis by writing some new concept on religion or have more fan-following among the fanatic groups. Similarly, there are many preachers who just preach hatred instead of the message of Love and unity because they are not well educated and they do not possess any spiritual realization.

The effect of teachings of Swami Dayananda was also there Dayanand Saraswati, Arya Samaj, and Root of Hindu-Sikh Tension which resulted in the formation of an opposing group called Singh Sabha Movement

Why do Jains worship the Hindu God 'Ganesha'?

Jains never worship dietes followed by Hindus. Jains worship Veetragi dev (Jinendra dev). All our Teerthankaras and every soul who attained salvation are Jinendra. Veetragi means free from all kinds of attachment, both physical and mental. If you see Jain God's idol at Terapanthi Digambar Jain temples, you will see that it's without clothes, ornaments, and weapons. There won't be any devi besides it as God doesn't have wife. Nor does he have children, family, friends, servants, any kind of property, or vehicle. He doesn't need anything. He is either in padmasan posture with both hands in his l

Jains never worship dietes followed by Hindus. Jains worship Veetragi dev (Jinendra dev). All our Teerthankaras and every soul who attained salvation are Jinendra. Veetragi means free from all kinds of attachment, both physical and mental. If you see Jain God's idol at Terapanthi Digambar Jain temples, you will see that it's without clothes, ornaments, and weapons. There won't be any devi besides it as God doesn't have wife. Nor does he have children, family, friends, servants, any kind of property, or vehicle. He doesn't need anything. He is either in padmasan posture with both hands in his lap or standing posture with both hands on side. His eyes are neither open nor closed. It's Nasa dhrashti. It means looking at the tip of nose. Closed eyes are a sign of lazyness and sleep while open eyes signifies raag (attachment) towards worldly and materialistic life. Hence, the eyes of idol is set on the tip of the nose. It conveys that God is not interested in worldly beings, worldly life, worldly pleasures or miseries or materials. He is meditating in his own soul and he gets divine pleasure and eternal bliss in that. He is never hungry or thirsty. He is never sleepy or tired. He never becomes ill. He never moves or travel. He is not impressed by anyone nor he will be angry on anyone. He doesn't reward or punish. He is neither creator nor destroyer. He is not a sustainer of the world either. He doesn't need anyone or anything to be happy as he is experiencing eternal bliss in his own soul. That's how our souls are too. Eternal bliss lies in our own soul but unlike Veetragi Lord Jinendra, we are not able to experience it because our soul is bounded by karma since time imemmorial. Lord Jinendra had destroyed all karma so he's experiencing eternal bliss. That's the reason we pray him. We don't pray to beg for worldly pleasures like it's done in some other religions. We pray to show respect towards him and we just wish that just like God destroyed all karma, may I get courage to do the same. There is a saying “Jain mandir bhikshalay nahin, Shikshalay hai”. It means Jain temple is not a place to beg for worldly pleasures. It is a place to learn to experience your soul to get eternal bliss. You can only experience soul once you have complete self absorption and detachment from the world and all kinds of worldly pleasures, people, and materialistic life. When you neither have raag (love or attachment) nor dhwesh (anger or hatred) It's called veetragta.

We don't refer idol as murti. We call it pratima which means reflection. Just like when you go near mirror, you are not interested to see the mirror. You are interested to see your reflection. Similarly, the purpose of praying idol is that we realize that our soul is just like this and if we follow the footsteps of God, we can be God too just like him. Despite having eternal bliss in our own soul, we try to find happiness in outside world. We have imagined that happiness is in family, friends, spouse, children, food, money, sex, car, big house, luxuries, luxurious lifestyle, good looks, fame, etc. But none last long. All those stuff just create illusion of happiness and doesn't have real happiness.

Coming to the point, why Jains pray Ganesha? No we don't. Jain aagams do acknowledge Shri Ram and Shri Krishna existed whom Hindus believe as God, but nowhere I found the mention of Bhrahma, Vishnu, Shiv, Parvati, Ganesha, Kali Mata, etc. I have not seen any Jain temple where there is idol of Ganesha. However, if any Jain temple has it, it's probably because he is believed to be the yaksha of Teerthankar’s samavasaran according to some Jain people. However, I have not read about Shri Ganesha in any Jain texts. To know what is samavasaran, please refer Samavasarana - Wikipedia and समवसरण की महिमा - ENCYCLOPEDIA

When Teerthankar attains kewal gyan (enlightenment) and becomes omniscient, the king of heaven Indra orders Kuber dev to create samavasaran, a divine preaching hall where Teerthankar preaches the path of salvation to human beings, heavenly beings, and animals. Yes, along with human beings, animals and heavenly beings also come to hear the preachings of Teerthankara. Many heavenly deities with supernatural power participate in samavasaran. Just like human beings, they also come to hear the preachings of Teerthankaras. There are also yaksha and yakshini in samavasaran who are one kind of heavenly deities. Some Jain temples may have idols of kshetrapal, Padmavati devi, etc but those idols are not main. The main idol (mul nayak) is of always Lord Jinendra (Teerthankar). The idols of heavenly deities are kept in the temple but most Jains don't worship them. They just show respect to them. Those idols are kept in Jain Temples just out of respect. It's like, you go to Temple to worship God but you also appreciate people who contributed in the construction of temple. Similarly, Jains show respect to those deities as they are also true followers of Teerthankaras, they took care of Teerthankaras' samavasaran.

There are a few Jains who worship heavenly deities but that doesn't mean those deities are God per Jainism. God is the one who is enlightened and who had achieved salvation. Those heavenly beings are subject to birth and death, just like us. Their life span is much longer than us and they also have supernatural powers as they are in heaven but their lifespan eventually ends and they can be reborn as human, animal, or even as tree or plant based on their karma. Heaven and hell are not eternal in Jainism. Many of the heavenly dieites including yakshas and yakshinis in Teerthankara’s Samavasaran are samyag dhrashti (self-realized) and they eventually attain salvation in their upcoming birth.

Those who worship deities for worldly pleasures, offers fruits and flowers to God, and believes in decorating idol of Lord Jinendra actually doesn't know the true form of God. God in Jainism - Wikipedia, The Concept of God in Jainism

Because such idols are found in Jain temples and because some sects of Jainism decorate idols, stick chakshu, offer flowers and fruits, I believe it is misunderstood and misinterpreted that Jainism is somewhat similar to Hinduism but it's not. It has nothing to do with Hinduism or Buddhism or any other religion. The base ideology of God as creator, sustainer, destroyer, punisher, or giver itself is not accepted in Jainism. Jainism is the only religion in the world which says God isn't creator, sustainer, or destroyer of the world and doesn't punish or reward anyone. We ourselves automatically bear fruit of our own karma, good or bad.

Is the idol of the deity in the Tirupati temple actually the idol of a Jain God?

Firstly lets know claims that the idol is of jain origin:

  • Idol of the god is not shown to public at all and is always covers with ornaments and garland, seems to be hiding something.
  • Jains claim the idol to be of 22nd tirtankara lord Neminath.
  • Idol does not pose shanka and chakra, they are added later.
  • There are no material evidence of Lord balaji in hindu puranas.

Lets look into each one individually.

1. First claim that idol (moola virat) is not shown is completely false as there exist a Seva at Tirupati call Nijapada Darshanam on friday where idol is decorated with minimal ornaments any one can see the idol of deity clearly wearing just a lowin cloth.

Yes it is true that there are no recent pictures of the deity without any decoration, but there exists a rare video of the deity in black and white taken during british time. This video is the only authentic source of the idol available. Picture from the video is attached below.

tirupati original idol video

Skip to 39 minutes in the video link attached above to watch original video of idols abhishekam without any ornaments and decorations.

As you can see clearly lord has a attached crown itself . No jain idol has any kind of crown adorned with it. Idol can be seen with a dhothi also crafted with stone, none of these features match any jain idol.

Claim that lords curly hair is covered with the golden crown. Yes it is true that lord has long curly hair on his back unlike curly hair of any jain idol. Also curly hair is not distinct for only jaina sculptures most of stone idols of many relegions bare this resemblance.

2. As for the second claim that the idol is of Lord Neminath is completely baseless.

This is the digambara idol of lord Neminatha.

This is the replica idol of lord Balaji.

As one can see clearly that there are no astounding resemblances to the two idols.

Lord Balaji’s pose is unique in stance having four hands two raised upwards and lower right hand showing Varada hasta and left hand showing Kati hasta. Lord has Godess Lakshmi crafted on his chest. On stark contrast jain idols normally never have any ornaments, crown and that distinct pose of the idol at Tirupati crafted within the stone idol.

Moola virat(idol) of lord is very special and is believed to be extra terrestrial object. Many miracles have happened over the years proving lords existance.

So it can be ruled out that the idol belongs to Lord Neminath.

3. Third claim is interesting as it is 100% true that lord does not have any shanka or chakra embedded on the idol itself but that does not mean that lord does not have four hands. Two of the upper hands are in the pose of getting hold weapons in both the hands as you can see in the picture below.

No jaina idol has a pose showing four hands and with upper hands holding any kind of weapon.

Lord Balaji has a unique story of why the shanka and chakra are missing. In a popular story lord presents his ardent devotee king Tondaman with his weapons to fight a war and also predicts that they will be returned by another devotee many years later. As predicted Sri Ramanujacharya presented with those weapons much later.

4. It is not true that there are no literary evidences of Tirupati being a vishnu temple. Even being a jain Tiruvalluar mentions about Vengadam. Silapathikaram mentions Lord Venkateshwara as an incarnation on Lord Vishnu. Vishnu purana also mentions Venkateshwara as the main deity of kaliyuga. Some argue that Venkateshwara mentioned by Tiruvalluar and also in Silapathikaram represent jain god. As the name suggests Eshwara means a hindu god either Shiva or Vishnu.

The above facts seem i think disprove all the claims “ with respect to everyone".

All are free to visit the temple and offer their worship but not to play with other relegions beliefs with false claims.

Everyone is welcome to the abode of lord.

Be it Lord Neminatha or Lord Venkateshwara or Lord Buddha, God is what you see and believe. Reach the abode of lord you shall find peace.

Myself am a ardent devotee of Lord Venkateshwara. Even after all these confusions we cannot deny that Tirupati is one of the most famous relegious place in the world much credit goes to hindus that.

“Venkatdhri samam sthanam brahmande nasthi kinchana Venkatesa samo devo na bhuto na bhavishyathi"

Meaning: There is no Shrine equal to Venkatdhri and there is no God on par with Lord Venkateshwara.

“ OM NAMO VENKATESHAYA “

Are Jain Tirthankaras Hindus?

Hindu is a word given by the Britishers to the Indians. Nowhere in history the word ‘Hindu’ is mentioned. Now if you take Hinduism as a religion, it in itself consists of many philosophies with different standpoints(like advaita, dwaita, vedanta etc) and sub-religions(like Vaishnavism, shaivism,brahmanism) bonded strongly together because of their faith in the 4 Vedas.

All the above philosophies and sub-religions of the religion Hinduism are different from one another but since they believe in the 4 Vedas and its authenticity they can be called as hindus.

In India, there has always existed two a

Hindu is a word given by the Britishers to the Indians. Nowhere in history the word ‘Hindu’ is mentioned. Now if you take Hinduism as a religion, it in itself consists of many philosophies with different standpoints(like advaita, dwaita, vedanta etc) and sub-religions(like Vaishnavism, shaivism,brahmanism) bonded strongly together because of their faith in the 4 Vedas.

All the above philosophies and sub-religions of the religion Hinduism are different from one another but since they believe in the 4 Vedas and its authenticity they can be called as hindus.

In India, there has always existed two ancient traditions i.e Vedic tradition(believer of vedas and the above mentioned philosophies and sub-religions) and the Sharmanic tradition (Jainism & Buddhism, non believer in vedas)

Buddhism originated on the seeds on the already established ancient Shramanic tradition whose origination is often stated in antiquity by researchers. The ancient Jainism was already an established faith during that time and was the inheritor of the same Shramanic tradition as today even, the jain ascetics are called as Shramanas(male) and shramanis(female). There is nowehere a word as ‘Jainism’ metioned in ancient books before the last Tirthankar, Mahavir Swami but only it is called by the names ‘Shramanas or Nirgranths’. It is only after the last Tirthankar, it came to be called as Jainism. Even in jain canons, the term nirgranthas or shramanas is often used.

The Shramanic tradition (Present day Jainism) rejects the authority of Vedas. It has its own set of Agamas ( canons/ teachings from the sermon of the last Tirthankara Mahavir Swami and other kevalis and are only considered reliable and authentic).

Both Vedic and Shramanic have been in this country side by side and have flourished with their own set of philosohies and are fundamentally different. The most basic difference is Vedics believe in a God and its avatar as a creator , sustainer and destroyer. Whereas Jainism does not believe in a creator, sustainer and destroyer God and are by nature athiest( just didn’t get the correct term for it but to say that there is no God according to common beliefs but godliness(when a being becomes omniscient, only he/she can be termed as God).

By all the above reasons, it is proved that neither Jainism is an offshot of Hinduism nor Hinduism is an offshot of Jainism. Both are fundamentally different but are the inheritors of the same ancient Indian culture(culture is different from religion.First culture(lifestyle,food habits etc) originated from 1st Tirthankar Rishabhadeva and then the religion was established).

PEACE!

Rami Sivan

I well remember the interest excited among the learned Hindus of Calcutta by the publication of the Sarva-darśana-saṃgraha of Mádhava Áchárya in the Bibliotheca Indica in 1858. It was originally edited by Paṇḍit Íśvarachandra Vidyáságara, but a subsequent edition, with no important alterations, was published in 1872 by Paṇḍit Táránátha Tarkaváchaspati. The work had been used by Wilson in his "Sketch of the Religious Sects of the Hindus" (first published in the Asiatic Researches, vol. xvi., Calcutta, 1828); but it does not appear to have been ever much known in India. MS. copies of it are very scarce; and those found in the North of India, as far as I have had an opportunity of examining them, seem to be all derived from one copy, brought originally from the South, and therefore written in the Telugu character. Certain mistakes are found in all alike, and probably arose from some illegible readings in the old Telugu original. I have noticed the same thing in the Nágarí copies of Mádhava's Commentary on the Black Yajur Veda, which are current in the North of India. As I was at that time the Oriental Secretary of the Bengal [vi] Asiatic Society, I was naturally attracted to the book; and I subsequently read it with my friend Paṇḍit Maheśachandra Nyáyaratna, the present Principal of the Sanskrit College at Calcutta. Why are only Hindus allowed inside some temples like the Puri Jagannath Temple, Madurai Temple, Tirupati etc.?

Why are only Hindus allowed inside some temples like the Puri Jagannath Temple, Madurai Temple, Tirupati etc.?

Why are only Hindus allowed inside some temples like the Puri Jagannath Temple, Madurai Temple, Tirupati etc.?

This is one of the question that vexes society. In one sense, I do not like non-Hindus to visit temples, because their motive is not worship, they come to gawk at what is exotic to them and take a flurry of pictures.

I was recently in Arunachala and there a group of women were lighting multiple lamps in a single plate and were doing aradhana at a shrine. Then comes along a white lady with her camera and start taking pictures, the ladies got distracted and started posing for the camera, to the end that the white women was directing them on how to stand to get the best light etc. And in the meantime, bhava was lost.

Who is to blame here?

But then there is no guarantee that every Hindu who visits a temple has similar devotion. Nor is that all non-Hindus come to gawk as tourists.

So it is a call the temples have to make, there is no perfect solution to such.

In my opinion, given my experience of Abrahamic religions, where they think to pray to "idols" is bizarre and exotic. I rather fall on the other side of the line, that they should not be allowed to visit the Shrines.

A Hindu can visit a Church or a Mosque, for a simple reason that a Hindu does not consider such a worship as pagan, heathen or mushrik. The Hindu does not stand in judgement. But Abrahamics do stand in judgement upon other religions.

I do not want to invite someone to my home, knowing that their motives are thus. And I don't want my heritage to be gawked at, or our practices - as though we are performing monkeys in a circus act.

Sure there will be exceptions to this, but it is near impossible to verify. So for now, I think it is better policy to keep them away.

Be it USCIRF or people like Jeffery Kripal, trusting them and giving them access, has turned out to be a bad choice for us. For they end up demeaning what we value.

We should stop being suckers for the "white person's opinion", we are proud that they appreciate our art, heritage etc. But every time this has lead to that particular art or custom, being stripped of its dharmic moorings and marketed as a "secularized" exotic product and slowly appropriated.

I know it is not intuitive for us to be suspicious. But it is better we learn from History.

Why aren't non-Jains allowed in Jain temples?
Originally Answered: Why aren't non jains allowed in JAIN temples?

I have never seen or heard any non-Jain not being allowed in any Jain temple.

Anyone from any caste or creed can visit any Jain temple or other place of worship. Not just that anyone can adopt / practice Jainism and if one so desires can even embrace Jain deeksha and become a Jain monk.

There is no such restriction in Jainism. In fact, you would find many Jain munis coming from non-Jain families.

So, feel free to visit any Jain temple, attend discourse of any Jain muni, visit them for any spiritual discussion / advice and go to whatever extent you feel like.

Deepaks surely do kill organisms.

Any Jain worships to attain the noble qualities possessed by the God. Alas, the mind loves to ponder over a lot of thoughts and wanders into evil line of thoughts by default. So, to worship we need some medium through which can focus our mind.

A deepak is quite beautiful. Its beauty entangles you and keeps your mind from wandering. At moments, we just can’t take our eyes off it, admiring its glow, finding immense peace just by looking at it.(Remember Diwali?)

Imagine it’s early evening, you are in a temple. No electricity. People are doing aarti with deepaks. That scene really is spectacular. (Also, electricity came around somewhere in the 19th century. Before that our ancestors would rely just on the oil lamps.)

But, now that we have electricity, so we should not burn deepaks? So, how is electricity produced? Does that happen in a non-violent manner?

The problem is that we cannot practice absolute non-violence in all areas of our lives. The goal here is to minimize it to the best possible extent (and without making lame excuses).

A soldier kills and a murderer does so too. One is a hero, the other is a criminal. The purpose behind the task is equally important to the deed.

Any Jain lighting deepak for worship fairly knows that he would not be doing so forever. One day he will become a monk and progressively, the God. To reach that stage, he needs to focus and train his mind now. Deepaks can help us there.

A Jain shravak would go to heaven and a Jain monk would possibly go to hell for lighting a deepak. (The former’s motive is to worship God, the later has already graduated from that stage).

The motive behind doing a task matters the most!

What are the parts of a Hindu temple in comparison with a Buddhist temple?

There is no comparison as the philosophy behind the temple structure is different.

The Hindu Agama temple represents the human body and the deity enshrined is a reflection (bimba) of the ātman. So each and every part of the temple has analogue to the human body and the body is symbolic of the Universe which is the “body” of God. Hinduism being pan-en-theistic.

The Buddhist temple on the other hand has no such symbolism and is just a structure which houses an image of the Buddha or Bodhisattva for the purpose of veneration and celebration. A Buddhist temple is built like a Royal palace - Prasād where the Buddha is a Royal personage.

Thanks for the A2A, apart from being a legal conundrum because legally, a person is supposed to be a follower of a single religion. I'll try a philosophical approach.

Indic religions like Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism and Sikhism have similar ideals and concept and there shouldn't be any problem or dilemma in reconciliation of diverse ideas. I know of Hindus in Punjab who would 'surrender' their child to Sikhism.

The problem comes with Abrahamic faiths like Christianity, Judaism and Islam. Abrahamic faith requires a certain level of detachment from their followers like for instance, Christianity demands that each and every Christian accept Jesus and only Jesus as their saviour and to accept the Holy Spirit as the ultimate truth or as Islam for instance doesn't tolerate bowing before any other god other than Islamic Allah. So, basically, a true adherent of Christianity or Islam cannot follow Hinduism or vice-versa.

Are Jains Hindu?

No, they are not.

That’s why they are classified as a separate religion.

Jainism was established by Vardhamana Mahavira around 6th century BCE.

But, Jains believe that their faith has come down to them from antiquity through a series of 24 Tirthankaras, the earliest of whom was Rishabhanatha, whom Jain legends depict as having lived millions of years ago, and the most recent, Mahavira.

So, Mahavira is not regarded as the founder of Jainism, but as the one who gave a new orientation to Jainism and shaped the modern faith.

Key differences between Hinduism and Jainism :

  • Jains don’t worship gods like Hindus do, but they do build temples and worship what they call divine beings.
  • Jains reject the Vedas and Vedic sacrifices.
  • Jains don’t believe in the concept of creator - believe the Universe is eternal and they believe that a immaterial entity can’t create a material entity like the Universe.
  • They see Ahimsa (non violence) as the rule of life.

Where as,

  • Hindus worship god/gods.
  • Most Hindus accept the authority of Vedas, Upanishads and Vedic practices such as Homa.
  • Hindus believe in the concept of Creator and creation, they believe in the cycle of creation and destruction.
  • Hindus believe that a certain degree of violence is essential for maintaining order in the society. (For example- a soldier has to fight, it is his dharma to do so, refusing to do his job would cause disorder)

Due to these key differences - Jainism was seen as an Atheistic sect by Hindus of post Vedic times.

Jains preached heavily against the Vedas, Vedic sacrifices and the ideology spread pretty quickly to all parts of the subcontinent and was seen as a major rival for post Vedic Hinduism and Buddhism.

They were also successful in gaining patronage from kings even down south.

For example the oldest Tamil inscriptions are about kings donating Rock beds to Jains.

Mangulam inscriptions of 3rd century BCE :

Translation : King Pandian Nedunchezian’s accountant named Kadalan Vazhudhi made this rock bed for a Jain monk named Nanda Sirikuvan

[1]

Similarly, most of the Post vedic Hindu scriptures are critical of Jains for misleading kings and people.

Padma Purana II.38.1-5 :

“Suta said: Vena, thus advised by that very sinful Jina, and deluded by him, attained to a sinful attitude. Abandoning the Vedic faith and rites of a truthful conduct, he saluted the feet of that very wicked one. There was cessation of good sacrifices, and also of that Vedas. Religious practices full of holy scriptures (i.e. as told in the holy scriptures) did not proceed at that time. As a result of (bad) rule, the world became full of all sins. When that king ruled, there were no sacrifices, no (recitation of) the Vedas, no excellent purport of the holy texts, no charity and no study, O brahmanas.”

[2]

Padma Purana gives us a sneek into the social conditions of the post Vedic times.

We can see that kings who converted Jainism abandoned Vedic practices. They also stopped supporting Brahmanas or Vedic schools, yagnas so on.

Historical records show that these things actually happened.

For example:

Kalabhra rule and their attitude towards Vedic religion:

The 8th century (800 AD) Velvikudi Copper plate inscriptions show that Kalabhras (who were Jains) who ruled Tamil countries from 400 AD to 700 AD stopped the practice of Brahmadeya.

Brahmadeya was the practice of granting lands to Brahmins for their sustenance.

The Kalabhra kings not only stopped the practice, they also seized the lands given to Brahmins by previous Sangam age rulers.

The inscriptions records Pandian Nedunjadaiyan's renewal of a grant made by his purported ancestor, the ancient Pandya king Palyaga Salai Mudukudimi Peruvaluti.

The inscription states that during the third year of Nedunjadaiyan's reign, a man arrived at the Pandya capital Kudal (Koodal or Madurai ), and complained that Velvikudi (a village) was donated to someone named Narkorran by Pandian Mudukudimi, but the Kalabhras had seized the lands.

After the revival of Pandiyan kingdom, the kings had promised to return the lands back, the complainant claimed that the lands had not been returned to Narkorran's descendants after the end of the Kalabhra interregnum.

The king asked the complainant to prove the antiquity of the grant, which the complainant did.

The king then granted the Velvikudi village to Kamakkani Narchingan (Kāmakaṇi Naṟchiṅgaṉ) alias Suvaran Singan, the headman of Korkai.

The headman kept the one-third of the village for himself, and distributed the remaining part among fifty other brahmanas.

[3]

Decline :

Bhakti movement is largely responsible for the decline of Jainism in the south and revival of Hindu sects of Shaivam and Vaishnavam.

Jainism and Jain kings were not seen in favorable light by the Bhakti literature.

Bhakti literature speaks of religious intolerance practiced by the Kalabhra kings.

For example:

Periyapuranam mentions that the Jain king who ruled Madurai, caused troubles to Shaivaites.

Thondaradi podi Alwar, in his thirumalai calls for killing of Jains and Buddhists who disparage Vishnu in one of his poems ( Tirumaalai 879.)

The Jain kings of the south started converting back to Hinduism, due to efforts of Bhakti movement.

For most part, the movement was non-violent, but there were incidents of violence against Jains like the supposed Jain massacre in Madurai. The violence in Tamil regions is not well documented, but we can see that the Jains were hated by proponents of Bhakti movement.

Jainism also lost patronage in the Telugu and Kannada speaking regions due to the efforts of Lingayats.

Jainism got a major set back in the region during Chola-Chalukya wars, due to violence against Jains by the Chola army. Jain Basadis were destroyed and major Jain centers were targeted .

[4]

Jain temples were destroyed or converted to Shaiva temples by the Veera Shaivites.

In the north, the Jainism had major set back due to Islamic invasions. A lot of Jain temples were destroyed during these invasions.

Are most Sikhs descendants of Hindu or Muslim converts?

I'm going to answer from a purely historical point of view, and avoid any flowery theological description that will no doubt be given in some of the answers here.

The vast, overwhelming majority of the original Sikhs (including Guru Nanak Dev ji himself) were Hindus who converted to Sikhism.

As time passed into the modern era, we can see that almost all Sikhs today are people who were born into Sikh families.

There were a handful of Muslims, but the vast majority of the original Sikhs were Hindu converts.

So it stands to reason that almost all Sikhs today are descended from Hindu converts, with a

I'm going to answer from a purely historical point of view, and avoid any flowery theological description that will no doubt be given in some of the answers here.

The vast, overwhelming majority of the original Sikhs (including Guru Nanak Dev ji himself) were Hindus who converted to Sikhism.

As time passed into the modern era, we can see that almost all Sikhs today are people who were born into Sikh families.

There were a handful of Muslims, but the vast majority of the original Sikhs were Hindu converts.

So it stands to reason that almost all Sikhs today are descended from Hindu converts, with a small minority of them being descended from Muslim converts.

Which are the Hindu gods worshiped by other religions like Jainism, Buddhism etc.?

Since, I am a Jain, I can tell only about Jainism.

In Jainism, none of the Hindu god is worshipped. We worship 'Tirthankaras'.

We also have scriptures with stories similar to that are present in Hinduism, such as Ramayana, Mahabharata, stories of Shri Krishna , etc but they are not worshipped as in Hinduism.

But you will find Jains going to Hindu temples and worshipping Hindu Gods and Goddesses, but that is not part of Jainism. We believe in Hindu gods & Goddesses but just that, they are not worshipped in Jainism.

At times English words used in quora question make answering the question difficult. Because OP has used the word procedure so pinpointing a particular procedure is difficult.But we will understand the journey. Also person asking this question can be both male or female.

Now this question can come from person who was Hindu or of any other religion and he/she read Sikh history and gurbani and is now inspired to adopt Sikhism completely.

  1. The first step has to be studying Gurbani and understanding its basic principles
  2. The second step is reading Sikh history of Guru's period and of period following guru’s period and understanding how Gurbani and its teachings are reflected in history.
  3. Starting reciting Gurbani daily and also understanding its meaning
  4. The next step is to visit Gurudwara daily & participating in Sewa

When a person does above 4 steps on daily basis, his or her connection with Sikhi gets strengthened each day. In my life I have closely seen 3–4 people who adopted Sikhism from other religions (Hinduism or Aethism)

1. Sanjay Sharma to Jasvinder Singh : He used to live in my locality in UP and was studious types. He read a lot about Gurbani philosophy from the literature available in local Gurudwara library. Learnt Punjabi. Used to actively participate in Sewa and finally took Amrit (Sikh baptism) and started tying turban.

2. 18 year old student of Guru Granth Sahib Vidya Kendra (Mehrauli, Delhi): He came from a village where he saw someone who became Sikh and how his lifestyle changed. That inspired him to become Sikh. He shifted to Guru Granth Sahib Vidya Kendra to complete his worldly studies as well as to learn about Sikhism

3. A final year engineering boy from Mumbai wanting to keep long hair and turban: Belonging to Radha Swami community and living in Mumbai suburbs, he started going to local Gurudwara and was inspired by Sakhis (historical episodes) from Sikh Guru’s lives and selfless service. In spite of opposition from his family, he kept telling them about his desire to keep long hairs and tie turban. Still on path to learn more about Sikhi

4. A close aide of the Congress leader Oscar Fernandes who was from the so called low Castes and was from Uttar Pradesh: He lived in rural area in Uttar Pradesh (Tarai region) on border of present day UP and Uttaranchal. He was 30+ years when he converted to Sikhism. I personally saw him coming to learn to tie turban to local Gurudwara.

5. I have personally received message on Quora/Facebook from 2 girls from other religion asking about conversion to Sikhism

6. Heena to Manjot Kaur: She was tuition teacher of my cousin sister. She was from Punjabi family going to both gurudwara and mandir. Her family’s male members did not tie turban. But she eventually took amrit and became full Sikh and also got married to amritdhari guy. she also started by going to gurudwara , participating in sewa ( selfless service) , reading gurbani and finally taking amrit.

7. Below post from social media which is self explanatory

6. As a final word on this answer and to summarize the journey to becoming Sikh starts with reading and understanding gurbani, followed by reading of Sikh history and then it is manifested in action and appearance of the person.
